description:
It is not available as an icon, or in the terminal. When you search for the tool and try: 
snap start validity-sensors-tools
error: access denied (try with sudo)
 or 
[sudo] password for test: 
error: snap "validity-sensors-tools" has no services

what is the point of this???
summary: Thsi tool does not even start

description: if i could rate this a 0 then it would be -45 stars it has no icon and when i click launch it doesn't work.

I'm running Kubuntu 20.10, and this tool finally made it possible for me to use the fingerprint sensor on my Thinkpad Yoga 1st gen. The sensor is a 138a:0090.

To those of you leaving VERY harsh reviews:

1. Coding takes time, you obviously have no idea of the amount of work needed to developp a small tool like this.

2. Learn to look into the documentation ffs! All the instructions are on the github's page.

3. Despite having the skills required to do it myself, I could never find the time to actually do it, so Iḿ very thankful to the developper for providing it for FREE.
It's not perfect, and I would rather give it 4 stars if it wasn't for all the bad reviews, but it works.

To the developper: keep up the good work and ignore the insulting comments. You did great ;)
summary: Does what it says it does provided that you read the instructions!

description: Does what it's supposed to do

sudo validity-sensors-tools.initializer
output:
Unable to access to USB devices
 validity-sensors-tools is installed as a snap.
 To allow it to function correctly you may need to run:
  sudo snap connect validity-sensors-tools:raw-usb
  sudo snap connect validity-sensors-tools:hardware-observe
summary: Cannot get it to work on the HP Probook
